t: “Oh*pn that you were like a brother to me Who*ln nursed at my mother’s breasts. If*iln I found you outdoors, I would kiss you; No*ln one would despise me, either.
I*ln would lead you and*i bring you Into*ln the house of my mother, who used to instruct me; I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink from the juice of my pomegranates.
Let*ln his left hand be under my head And*ln his right hand embrace me.”
“I*ln want you to swear, O daughters of Jerusalem, Do*ln not arouse or awaken my*i love Until*ln she pleases.”

“Who*ln is this coming up from the wilderness Leaning*ln on her beloved?” “Beneath*bln the apple tree I awakened you; There*ln your mother was in labor with you, There*ln she was in labor and*i gave you birth.

Put*ln me like a seal over your heart, Like*ln a seal on your arm. For*ln love is as strong as death, Jealousy*ln is as severe as Sheol; Its*ln flashes are flashes of fire, The*ln very*i flame of the Lord.*s
Many*ln waters cannot quench love, Nor*ln will rivers overflow it; If*ln a man were to give all the riches of his house for love, It*ln would be utterly despised.”
“We*ln have a little sister, And*ln she has no breasts; What*ln shall we do for our sister On*ln the day when she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, We*ln will build on her a battlement of silver; But*ln if she is a door, We*ln will barricade her with planks of cedar.”
“I*ln was a wall, and my breasts were like towers; Then*ln I became in his eyes as one who finds peace.
Solomon*ln had a vineyard at Baal-hamon; He*ln entrusted the vineyard to caretakers. Each*ln one was to bring a thousand shekels*i of silver for its fruit.
My*ln very own vineyard is at my disposal; The*ln thousand shekels*i are for you, Solomon, And*ln two hundred are for those who take care of its fruit.”
“O*ln you who sit in the gardens, My*iln companions are listening for your voice— Let*ln me hear it!”
“Hurry,*ln my beloved, And*ln be like a gazelle or a young stag On*ln the mountains of spices.”
